014package org.jdbi.v3.core;
015
016import java.sql.Connection;
017import java.sql.DriverManager;
018import java.sql.SQLException;
019import java.util.Objects;
020import java.util.Properties;
021import java.util.ServiceLoader;
022import java.util.concurrent.CopyOnWriteArrayList;
023import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicReference;
024
025import javax.sql.DataSource;
026
027import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.ConfigRegistry;
028import org.jdbi.v3.core.config.Configurable;
029import org.jdbi.v3.core.extension.ExtensionCallback;
030import org.jdbi.v3.core.extension.ExtensionConsumer;
031import org.jdbi.v3.core.extension.ExtensionFactory;
032import org.jdbi.v3.core.extension.Extensions;
033import org.jdbi.v3.core.extension.HandleSupplier;
034import org.jdbi.v3.core.extension.NoSuchExtensionException;
035import org.jdbi.v3.core.internal.OnDemandExtensions;
036import org.jdbi.v3.core.internal.exceptions.Unchecked;
037import org.jdbi.v3.core.spi.JdbiPlugin;
038import org.jdbi.v3.core.statement.DefaultStatementBuilder;
039import org.jdbi.v3.core.statement.StatementBuilder;
040import org.jdbi.v3.core.statement.StatementBuilderFactory;
041import org.jdbi.v3.core.transaction.LocalTransactionHandler;
042import org.jdbi.v3.core.transaction.TransactionHandler;
043import org.jdbi.v3.core.transaction.TransactionIsolationLevel;
044import org.slf4j.Logger;
045import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
046
047import static java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS;
048import static java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS;
049
050/**
051 * Main entry point; configurable wrapper around a JDBC {@link DataSource}.
052 * Use it to obtain Handle instances and provide configuration
053 * for all handles obtained from it.
054 */
055public class Jdbi implements Configurable<Jdbi> {
056    private static final Logger LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(Jdbi.class);
057
058    private final ConfigRegistry config = new ConfigRegistry();
059
060    private final ConnectionFactory connectionFactory;
061    private final AtomicReference<TransactionHandler> transactionhandler = new AtomicReference<>(LocalTransactionHandler.binding());
062    private final AtomicReference<StatementBuilderFactory> statementBuilderFactory = new AtomicReference<>(DefaultStatementBuilder.FACTORY);
063
064    private final CopyOnWriteArrayList<JdbiPlugin> plugins = new CopyOnWriteArrayList<>();
065
066    @SuppressWarnings("ThreadLocalUsage")
067    private final ThreadLocal<HandleSupplier> threadHandleSupplier = new ThreadLocal<>();
068
069    private Jdbi(ConnectionFactory connectionFactory) {
070        Objects.requireNonNull(connectionFactory, "null connectionFactory");
071        this.connectionFactory = connectionFactory;
072    }
073
074    /**
075     * Creates a new {@link Jdbi} object from a {@link Connection}.
076     *
077     * @param connection A {@link Connection} object.
078     *
079     * @return A {@link Jdbi} instance that uses a single database connection.
080     */
081    public static Jdbi create(Connection connection) {
082        return create(new SingleConnectionFactory(connection));
083    }
084
085    /**
086     * Creates a new {@link Jdbi} object from a {@link DataSource}.
087     *
088     * @param dataSource the data source.
089     *
090     * @return a Jdbi which uses the given data source as a connection factory.
091     */
092    public static Jdbi create(DataSource dataSource) {
093        return create(dataSource::getConnection);
094    }
095
096    /**
097     * Factory used to allow for obtaining a Connection in a customized manner.
098     *
099     * <p>
100     * The {@link ConnectionFactory#openConnection()} method will be invoked to obtain a connection instance
101     * whenever a Handle is opened.
102     * </p>
103     *
104     * @param connectionFactory Provides JDBC connections to Handle instances
105     *
106     * @return a Jdbi which uses the given connection factory.
107     */
108    public static Jdbi create(ConnectionFactory connectionFactory) {
109        return new Jdbi(connectionFactory);
110    }
111
112    /**
113     * Creates a new {@link Jdbi} instance from a database URL.
114     *
115     * @param url A JDBC URL for connections.
116     *
117     * @return a Jdbi which uses{@link DriverManager} as a connection factory.
118     */
119    public static Jdbi create(final String url) {
120        Objects.requireNonNull(url, "null url");
121        return create(() -> DriverManager.getConnection(url));
122    }
123
124    /**
125     * Creates a new {@link Jdbi} instance from a database URL.
126     *
127     * @param url   JDBC URL for connections
128     * @param properties Properties to pass to DriverManager.getConnection(url, props) for each new handle
129     *
130     * @return a Jdbi which uses {@link DriverManager} as a connection factory.
131     */
132    public static Jdbi create(final String url, final Properties properties) {
133        Objects.requireNonNull(url, "null url");
134        Objects.requireNonNull(properties, "null properties");
135        return create(() -> DriverManager.getConnection(url, properties));
136    }
137
138    /**
139     * Creates a new {@link Jdbi} instance from a database URL.
140     *
141     * @param url      JDBC URL for connections
142     * @param username User name for connection authentication
143     * @param password Password for connection authentication
144     *
145     * @return a Jdbi which uses {@link DriverManager} as a connection factory.
146     */
147    public static Jdbi create(final String url, final String username, final String password) {
148        Objects.requireNonNull(url, "null url");
149        Objects.requireNonNull(username, "null username");
150        Objects.requireNonNull(password, "null password");
151        return create(() -> DriverManager.getConnection(url, username, password));
152    }
153
154    /**
155     * Convenience method used to obtain a handle from a specific data source
156     *
157     * @param dataSource the JDBC data source.
158     *
159     * @return Handle using a Connection obtained from the provided DataSource
160     */
161    public static Handle open(DataSource dataSource) {
162        return create(dataSource).open();
163    }
164
165    /**
166     * Convenience method used to obtain a handle from a {@link ConnectionFactory}.
167     *
168     * @param connectionFactory the connection factory
169     *
170     * @return Handle using a Connection obtained from the provided connection factory
171     */
172    public static Handle open(ConnectionFactory connectionFactory) {
173        return create(connectionFactory).open();
174    }
175
176    /**
177     * Create a Handle wrapping a particular JDBC Connection
178     *
179     * @param connection the JDBC connection
180     *
181     * @return Handle bound to connection
182     */
183    public static Handle open(final Connection connection) {
184        Objects.requireNonNull(connection, "null connection");
185        return create(() -> connection).open();
186    }
187
188    /**
189     * Obtain a handle with just a JDBC URL
190     *
191     * @param url JDBC Url
192     *
193     * @return newly opened Handle
194     */
195    public static Handle open(final String url) {
196        return create(url).open();
197    }
198
199    /**
200     * Obtain a handle with just a JDBC URL
201     *
202     * @param url      JDBC Url
203     * @param username JDBC username for authentication
204     * @param password JDBC password for authentication
205     *
206     * @return newly opened Handle
207     */
208    public static Handle open(final String url, final String username, final String password) {
209        return create(url, username, password).open();
210    }
211
212    /**
213     * Obtain a handle with just a JDBC URL
214     *
215     * @param url   JDBC Url
216     * @param props JDBC properties
217     *
218     * @return newly opened Handle
219     */
220    public static Handle open(final String url, final Properties props) {
221        return create(url, props).open();
222    }
223
224    /**
225     * Use the {@link ServiceLoader} API to detect and install plugins automagically.
226     * Some people consider this feature dangerous; some consider it essential --
227     * use at your own risk.
228     * @return this
229     */
230    public Jdbi installPlugins() {
231        ServiceLoader.load(JdbiPlugin.class).forEach(this::installPlugin);
232        LOG.debug("Automatically installed plugins {}", plugins);
233        return this;
234    }
235
236    /**
237     * Install a given {@link JdbiPlugin} instance that will configure any
238     * provided {@link Handle} instances.
239     * @param plugin the plugin to install
240     * @return this
241     */
242    public Jdbi installPlugin(JdbiPlugin plugin) {
243        if (plugins.addIfAbsent(plugin)) {
244            Unchecked.consumer(plugin::customizeJdbi).accept(this);
245        }
246        return this;
247    }
248
249    /**
250     * Allows customization of how prepared statements are created. When a Handle is created
251     * against this Jdbi instance the factory will be used to create a StatementBuilder for
252     * that specific handle. When the handle is closed, the StatementBuilder's close method
253     * will be invoked.
254     *
255     * @param factory the new statement builder factory.
256     * @return this
257     */
258    public Jdbi setStatementBuilderFactory(StatementBuilderFactory factory) {
259        this.statementBuilderFactory.set(factory);
260        return this;
261    }
262
263    /**
264     * Returns the current {@link StatementBuilderFactory}.
265     *
266     * @return the current {@link StatementBuilderFactory}
267     */
268    public StatementBuilderFactory getStatementBuilderFactory() {
269        return this.statementBuilderFactory.get();
270    }
271
272    @Override
273    public ConfigRegistry getConfig() {
274        return config;
275    }
276
277    /**
278     * Specify the TransactionHandler instance to use. This allows overriding
279     * transaction semantics, or mapping into different transaction
280     * management systems.
281     * <p>
282     * The default version uses local transactions on the database Connection
283     * instances obtained.
284     * </p>
285     *
286     * @param handler The TransactionHandler to use for all Handle instances obtained
287     *                from this Jdbi
288     * @return this
289     */
290    public Jdbi setTransactionHandler(TransactionHandler handler) {
291        Objects.requireNonNull(handler, "null transaction handler");
292        this.transactionhandler.set(handler);
293        return this;
294    }
295
296    /**
297     * Returns the {@link TransactionHandler}.
298     *
299     * @return the {@link TransactionHandler}
300     */
301    public TransactionHandler getTransactionHandler() {
302        return this.transactionhandler.get();
303    }
304
305    /**
306     * Obtain a Handle to the data source wrapped by this Jdbi instance.
307     * You own this expensive resource and are required to close it or
308     * risk leaks.  Using a {@code try-with-resources} block is recommended.
309     *
310     * @return an open Handle instance
311     * @see #useHandle(HandleConsumer)
312     * @see #withHandle(HandleCallback)
313     */
314    public Handle open() {
315        try {
316            final long start = System.nanoTime();
317            @SuppressWarnings("PMD.CloseResource")
318            Connection conn = Objects.requireNonNull(connectionFactory.openConnection(),
319                    () -> "Connection factory " + connectionFactory + " returned a null connection");
320            final long stop = System.nanoTime();
321
322            for (JdbiPlugin p : plugins) {
323                conn = p.customizeConnection(conn);
324            }
325
326            StatementBuilder cache = statementBuilderFactory.get().createStatementBuilder(conn);
327            Handle h = new Handle(this, config.createCopy(), connectionFactory::closeConnection, transactionhandler.get(), cache, conn);
328            for (JdbiPlugin p : plugins) {
329                h = p.customizeHandle(h);
330            }
331            LOG.trace("Jdbi [{}] obtain handle [{}] in {}ms", this, h, MILLISECONDS.convert(stop - start, NANOSECONDS));
332            return h;
333        } catch (SQLException e) {
334            throw new ConnectionException(e);
335        }
336    }
337
338    /**
339     * A convenience function which manages the lifecycle of a handle and yields it to a callback
340     * for use by clients.
341     *
342     * @param callback A callback which will receive an open Handle
343     * @param <R> type returned by the callback
344     * @param <X> exception type thrown by the callback, if any.
345     *
346     * @return the value returned by callback
347     *
348     * @throws X any exception thrown by the callback
349     */
350    public <R, X extends Exception> R withHandle(HandleCallback<R, X> callback) throws X {
351        if (threadHandleSupplier.get() != null) {
352            return callback.withHandle(threadHandleSupplier.get().getHandle());
353        }
354
355        try (Handle h = this.open()) {
356            threadHandleSupplier.set(new ConstantHandleSupplier(h));
357            return callback.withHandle(h);
358        } finally {
359            threadHandleSupplier.remove();
360        }
361    }
362
363    /**
364     * A convenience function which manages the lifecycle of a handle and yields it to a callback
365     * for use by clients.
366     *
367     * @param consumer A callback which will receive an open Handle
368     * @param <X> exception type thrown by the callback, if any.
369     *
370     * @throws X any exception thrown by the callback
371     */
372    public <X extends Exception> void useHandle(final HandleConsumer<X> consumer) throws X {
373        withHandle(consumer.asCallback());
374    }
375
376    /**
377     * A convenience function which manages the lifecycle of a handle and yields it to a callback
378     * for use by clients. The handle will be in a transaction when the callback is invoked, and
379     * that transaction will be committed if the callback finishes normally, or rolled back if the
380     * callback raises an exception.
381     *
382     * @param callback A callback which will receive an open Handle, in a transaction
383     * @param <R> type returned by the callback
384     * @param <X> exception type thrown by the callback, if any.
385     *
386     * @return the value returned by callback
387     *
388     * @throws X any exception thrown by the callback
389     */
390    public <R, X extends Exception> R inTransaction(final HandleCallback<R, X> callback) throws X {
391        return withHandle(handle -> handle.<R, X>inTransaction(callback));
392    }
393
394    /**
395     * A convenience function which manages the lifecycle of a handle and yields it to a callback
396     * for use by clients. The handle will be in a transaction when the callback is invoked, and
397     * that transaction will be committed if the callback finishes normally, or rolled back if the
398     * callback raises an exception.
399     *
400     * @param callback A callback which will receive an open Handle, in a transaction
401     * @param <X> exception type thrown by the callback, if any.
402     *
403     * @throws X any exception thrown by the callback
404     */
405    public <X extends Exception> void useTransaction(final HandleConsumer<X> callback) throws X {
406        useHandle(handle -> handle.useTransaction(callback));
407    }
408
409    /**
410     * A convenience function which manages the lifecycle of a handle and yields it to a callback
411     * for use by clients. The handle will be in a transaction when the callback is invoked, and
412     * that transaction will be committed if the callback finishes normally, or rolled back if the
413     * callback raises an exception.
414     *
415     * <p>
416     * This form accepts a transaction isolation level which will be applied to the connection
417     * for the scope of this transaction, after which the original isolation level will be restored.
418     * </p>
419     *
420     * @param level the transaction isolation level which will be applied to the connection for the scope of this
421     *              transaction, after which the original isolation level will be restored.
422     * @param callback A callback which will receive an open Handle, in a transaction
423     * @param <R> type returned by the callback
424     * @param <X> exception type thrown by the callback, if any.
425     *
426     * @return the value returned by callback
427     *
428     * @throws X any exception thrown by the callback
429     */
430    public <R, X extends Exception> R inTransaction(final TransactionIsolationLevel level, final HandleCallback<R, X> callback) throws X {
431        return withHandle(handle -> handle.inTransaction(level, callback));
432    }
433
434    /**
435     * A convenience function which manages the lifecycle of a handle and yields it to a callback
436     * for use by clients. The handle will be in a transaction when the callback is invoked, and
437     * that transaction will be committed if the callback finishes normally, or rolled back if the
438     * callback raises an exception.
439     *
440     * <p>
441     * This form accepts a transaction isolation level which will be applied to the connection
442     * for the scope of this transaction, after which the original isolation level will be restored.
443     * </p>
444     *
445     * @param level the transaction isolation level which will be applied to the connection for the scope of this
446     *              transaction, after which the original isolation level will be restored.
447     * @param callback A callback which will receive an open Handle, in a transaction
448     * @param <X> exception type thrown by the callback, if any.
449     *
450     * @throws X any exception thrown by the callback
451     */
452    public <X extends Exception> void useTransaction(final TransactionIsolationLevel level, final HandleConsumer<X> callback) throws X {
453        useHandle(handle -> handle.useTransaction(level, callback));
454    }
455
456    /**
457     * A convenience method which opens an extension of the given type, yields it to a callback, and returns the result
458     * of the callback. A handle is opened if needed by the extension, and closed before returning to the caller.
459     *
460     * @param extensionType the type of extension.
461     * @param callback      a callback which will receive the extension.
462     * @param <R> the return type
463     * @param <E> the extension type
464     * @param <X> the exception type optionally thrown by the callback
465     * @return the value returned by the callback.
466     * @throws NoSuchExtensionException if no {@link ExtensionFactory} is registered which supports the given extension
467     *                                  type.
468     * @throws X                        if thrown by the callback.
469     */
470    public <R, E, X extends Exception> R withExtension(Class<E> extensionType, ExtensionCallback<R, E, X> callback)
471            throws X {
472        if (threadHandleSupplier.get() != null) {
473            return callWithExtension(extensionType, callback, threadHandleSupplier.get());
474        }
475
476        try (LazyHandleSupplier handleSupplier = new LazyHandleSupplier(this, config)) {
477            threadHandleSupplier.set(handleSupplier);
478            return callWithExtension(extensionType, callback, handleSupplier);
479        } finally {
480            threadHandleSupplier.remove();
481        }
482    }
483
484    private <R, E, X extends Exception> R callWithExtension(Class<E> extensionType,
485                                                            ExtensionCallback<R, E, X> callback,
486                                                            HandleSupplier handle) throws X {
487        E extension = getConfig(Extensions.class)
488            .findFor(extensionType, handle)
489            .orElseThrow(() -> new NoSuchExtensionException(extensionType));
490
491        return callback.withExtension(extension);
492    }
493
494    /**
495     * A convenience method which opens an extension of the given type, and yields it to a callback. A handle is opened
496     * if needed by the extention, and closed before returning to the caller.
497     *
498     * @param extensionType the type of extension
499     * @param callback      a callback which will receive the extension
500     * @param <E>           the extension type
501     * @param <X>           the exception type optionally thrown by the callback
502     * @throws NoSuchExtensionException if no {@link ExtensionFactory} is registered which supports the given extension type.
503     * @throws X                        if thrown by the callback.
504     */
505    public <E, X extends Exception> void useExtension(Class<E> extensionType, ExtensionConsumer<E, X> callback)
506            throws X {
507        withExtension(extensionType, extension -> {
508            callback.useExtension(extension);
509            return null;
510        });
511    }
512
513    /**
514     * Creates an extension instance that uses the current {@link Jdbi} instance for database operations.
515     *
516     * @param extensionType the type of extension. Must be a public interface type.
517     * @param <E> the extension type
518     *
519     * @return an extension which opens and closes handles (as needed) for individual method calls. Only public
520     * interface types may be used as on-demand extensions.
521     */
522    public <E> E onDemand(Class<E> extensionType) {
523        if (!extensionType.isInterface()) {
524            throw new IllegalArgumentException("On-demand extensions are only supported for interfaces.");
525        }
526        if (!getConfig(Extensions.class).hasExtensionFor(extensionType)) {
527            throw new NoSuchExtensionException("Extension not found: " + extensionType);
528        }
529
530        return getConfig(OnDemandExtensions.class).create(this, extensionType);
531    }
532}
